awd_titl_txt: Conference: Developing Effective Tools for Leading Sustainable Campus Culture Change in Hispanic-Serving Institutions to Eliminate Equity Gaps in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI Program), this conference proposal aims to create and validate institutional self-assessments to inform HSI campus academic leadership, as they lead culture change to increase the numbers of successful students in STEM courses and programs. This work will create a unique tool to help campus leaders understand the steps they can take to assure their campus’ culture really supports Hispanic students’ success. The impact of this work will increase the academic success of diverse students in STEM careers that is reflective of national demographics.

Based on two years of in-depth research, four levers for campus culture change needed to remove equity gaps for student success were identified and validated.  The National Center for Higher Education Management Systems (NCHEMS) plans to create campus-level self-assessment tools related to those levers to allow campus leaders at HSIs, to understand and share with institutional stakeholders how well they are doing in supporting Hispanic students in STEM fields. In addition, the convening of academic leaders will provide a space for them to identify the policies and practices needed to address equitable STEM academic success. Individuals within two groups of five HSI presidents each (one from community colleges, the other from four-year colleges and universities) will work together to help the researchers evaluate the practical application of the tools and allow them to create useable resources for other colleges/university leaders. The tools will enable leaders who are new to the HSI designation to have a starting place to reorient the campus community toward greater student success in STEM fields.  The methodology is based on past successful practices in developing campus self-assessment tools. The tools will be disseminated through presidential associations where HSI leaders gather. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes of the award:

Researchers recruited five community college and five university presidents from Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI) across the U.S.  Each of them agreed to review the draft versions of self-assessment tools and to participate in the convenings to discuss and offer feedback on these tools as part of an advisory group. The tools were in the form of self-assessment questionnaires meant to promote reflection among the senior leaders at campuses. The tools were based on the previous research of the Foundation for Student Success (FSS). That research includes information collected over a two-year period from site visits, surveys, reports and regular discussions among small groups of the 28 campuses participating. Through that research, four levers for leading campus culture transformation enabling the elimination/reduction of equity gaps for Black, Hispanic and American Indian students were identified. The levers are: 1) Data collection, analysis and use; 2) Effective institution-wide communication and engagement; 3) Hiring strategies and personnel policies; and 4) Audit of institution and state policies and practices to identify those that perpetuate lower student achievement. A self-assessment tool was created for each of the four levers and the research team crafted the questions to focus on Hispanic students in STEM programs.

The campus leaders who participated in the convenings were:

 

Universities

President Cathy Sandeen, California State University—East Bay

President DeRionne Pollard, Nevada State University

President Jack Warner, Rhode Island College

President Joseph Shepard, Western New Mexico University

President Neal Smatresk, University of North Texas

Community Colleges

President Eric Leshinskie, Scottsdale Community College, Arizona

President Rhonda Epper, Trinadad State College, Colorado

President Pam Eddinger, Bunker Hill Community College, Massachusetts

President Adena Williams Loston, St. Philip’s College, Texas

President Chris Villa, Skagit Valley College, Washington

 

Each president brought unique perspectives on the self-assessment tools, shaped by their campus experiences and their own state’s political realities. The discussions guided the refinement of the tools so they could be as useful as possible to other HSI campus leaders.

The final version of the tools went through a professional design process so they could be published electronically as Open Education Resources. The advisory group recommended printing copies and mailing the tools out to get the attention of other campus leaders. So, they were professionally printed and mailed to other community college and university presidents. The CEOs of higher education membership organizations and accrediting agencies were also mailed a copy of the tools for use in their presidential training programs.

In addition, the staff of the Aspen Institute College Excellence Program and Excelencia in Education have requested training on the use of the tools and the researchers will conduct those trainings.

 

Intellectual Merit

Considering the precipitous growth in the number of individuals leading HSIs in the United States and the inequities that exist in access to and participation in all aspects of STEM education, research, and the workforce, these convenings provided important opportunities for campus leaders. The convenings offered the advisory group opportunities to engage in structured problem-solving with peers, all working toward the shared goal of creating practical tools for self-assessing campus culture transformation. These tools, designed for use on their campuses, are available for free download, use, and adaptation by others at https://nchems.org/project/foundation-for-student-success/.

Leadership of newer HSIs may be committed to success for their Hispanic students but few know how to get started. These tools are one more way to help them begin this process of moving past a single initiative (e.g., Guided Pathways) and taking a more holistic approach to supporting the intersecting social identities of students. These tools have the potential to catalyze change in institutional practices and policies that have perpetuated racial and ethnic inequities in STEM education.

 

Broader Impacts

The project activities resulted in practical tools guiding leaders of HSIs and emerging HSIs on how to launch and sustain campus culture transformation agendas on their campuses to close equity gaps in Hispanic students’ participation and success in STEM programs. The self-assessment tools have the potential to influence shared attitudes, values, goals and practices so that leaders are better aligned with serving the intersecting identities of students. The ultimate desired societal outcomes are to increase the number and proportion of Hispanic students entering and succeeding in STEM educational programs and to increase the representation of Hispanic workers in STEM careers. These efforts have the potential to accelerate the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. There is also the potential to positively impact the U.S. economy by meeting growing demand in various STEM fields, especially the industries of the future as defined by NSF.
